html:
Pronunciation[edit]

  • (Classical) IPA(key): /ˈtak.soː/, [ˈt̪ak.soː]
  • (Ecclesiastical) IPA(key): /ˈtak.so/, [ˈt̪ak.sɔ]

Etymology 1[edit]

From tangō (“I touch”).

Verb[edit]

taxō (present infinitive taxāre, perfect active taxāvī, supine taxātum); first conjugation

  1. I feel, I touch sharply, I handle.
  2. I charge, I twit, I reproach, I censure.
  3. I rate, I appraise, I value, I estimate.
  4. I judge, I compute, I reckon, I estimate.

Synonyms[edit]
  • (I touch): tangō, tractō
  • (I value): aestimō
Derived terms[edit]
  • taxātiō
Descendants[edit]
  • Catalan: taxar
  • → English: tax
  • French: taxer, tâcher
  • Galician: taxar
  • Italian: tassare
  • → Norwegian Bokmål: taksere
  • Portuguese: taxar
  • Romanian: taxa
  • Spanish: tasar

Etymology 2[edit]

Ultimately from Proto-Germanic *þahsuz (“badger”), probably from Proto-Indo-European *teḱs- (“construct”) after the badger's construction of its setts. See texō.

Alternative forms[edit]

  • taxus

Noun[edit]

taxō m (genitive taxonis); third declension

  1. (Late Latin) badger
Declension[edit]

Third-declension noun.

Case Singular Plural
Nominative taxō taxonēs
Genitive taxonis taxonum
Dative taxonī taxonibus
Accusative taxonem taxonēs
Ablative taxone taxonibus
Vocative taxō taxonēs
Descendants[edit]

See also descendants at taxus.

  • Catalan: toixó
  • Old French: taisson
    • ⇒ Middle French: taisnere, tesniere
      • French: tanière
  • Spanish: tejón, texon
    • → Tetelcingo Nahuatl: texu

References[edit]

  • taxo in Charlton T. Lewis and Charles Short (1879) A Latin Dictionary, Oxford: Clarendon Press
  • taxo in Charles du Fresne du Cange’s Glossarium Mediæ et Infimæ Latinitatis (augmented edition, 1883–1887)
  • taxo in Gaffiot, Félix (1934) Dictionnaire Illustré Latin-Français, Hachette
